page.title: 03WEALDEN IRON, BEDGEBURY AREA
page.content: Mining and smelting of Wealden iron ore began before the Roman conquest, reached its peak in Tudor times and ended by about 1800. Archaeological features, names and chalybeate springs remind us of the former industry. The most abundant deposits were found in the Wadhurst Clay near its junction with the Tunbridge Wells or Ashdown Sand, generally the latter. Numerous small ponds are minepits from which iron was extracted and taken to nearby furnaces for smelting. Larger lakes were formed to provide power for furnace bellows or smelting hammers, usually known as Furnace or Hammer Pond, a Pond Bay being the dam. Known furnaces here are at Frith Farm and Furnace Farm, the latter less than a mile from the Bedgebury Forge, at Forge Farm to the northwest, which was operative till about 1600.
